channel.title: Mastodon Home Timeline

item.title: Climatematch
item.description: Applications are open for the second annual Climatematch Academy! We've made some awesome updates to the Computational Tools for Climate Science course. You won't want to miss it! 🌍 🌎 🌏 ➡️ Apply to be a student or TA here: https://neuromatch.io/courses/

item.title: Carl Zimmer
item.description: I wrote about people in Ethiopia who lived through a climate disaster 74,000 years ago, thanks to resilience and technological versatility. Some scientists think that they are the key to understanding how modern humans finally expanded out of Africa and survived on other continents permanently. Gift link: https://www.nytimes.com/2024/03/20/science/early-humans-arrowheads-volcano.html?ugrp=m&unlocked_article_code=1.eE0.iVZQ.hPHzM5P2M0Sx&smid=url-share

item.title: Jonathan Joshua
item.description: Great summary of TFG's legal options re filling bankruptcy as a delaying tactic.https://www.creditslips.org/creditslips/2024/03/a-trump-bankruptcy.html

item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description:
New results!Despite their varied molecular actions, anesthetics alter brain wave alignment in the same way.Convergent effects of different anesthetics are due to changes in phase alignment of cortical oscillations
https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2024.03.20.585943v1
#neuroscience

item.title: Luiz Pessoa
item.description:
TODAY: 𝗔𝗿𝗲 𝗽𝘀𝘆𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗮𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗰 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗼𝗿𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗯𝗿𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗼𝗿𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀?Check time difference given US spring time already.
Today: 12pm US, eastern time Neuroscience & Philosophy Salon with Anneli Jefferson and @awaisaftab with commentaries by @eikofried @NicoleCRust and Alexey TolchisnkyRegister:
umd.zoom.us/meeting/regi...

item.title: Alex Wild
item.description: Several of us overly online biologists spent years quietly doing an experiment on Twitter, trying to find out if tweeting about new studies from a set of mid-range journals caused an increase in later citations, compared to set of untweeted control articles.Turns out we had no noticeable effect; the tweeted papers were cited at the same rate as the control set. Our paper, headed by Trevor Branch, was published today in PLOS One:#SciComm #Twitter #X #Sciencehttps://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0292201

item.title: Yohan John 🤖🧠
item.description: How seriously should we take "levels" of reality? I mean the parcellation of the universe into, say, the particle level, the chemical level, the cellular level, the organism, individual level, the social/ecological level etc?Do levels interpenetrate?Are these metaphysical matters or just pragmatic ones?Stimulated by the great session on mental disorders just completed, hosted by @PessoaBrain , featuring Anneli Jefferson, @awaisaftab , @NicoleCRust , Alexey Tolchinky & @eikofried

item.title: Carl Zimmer
item.description: In my email newsletter today, I explore the hallmarks of life, why scientists don't agree on them, and whether A.I. can help broker an understanding. Contains a groovy organoid GIF. Check it out! https://buttondown.email/carlzimmer/archive/fridays-elk-march-22-2024/

item.title: Jay Kuo
item.description: Trump is about to engage in the biggest grift of his life and to become the “publicly traded” presidential candidate. That has enormous implications for this election and carries new dangers to our democracy—something vastly underreported by the media. https://open.substack.com/pub/statuskuo/p/the-publicly-traded-presidential?r=1zr8b&utm_campaign=post&utm_medium=web&showWelcomeOnShare=true

item.title: Dorothy Bishop
item.description:
I recommend this blogpost by Eiko Fried to anyone who is trying to fight the good fight in improving science and getting demoralised
https://eiko-fried.com/antidotes-to-cynicism-creep/
#OpenScience #Reproducibility #integrity

item.title: Matteo Carandini
item.description: In 1637 René Descartes published his “Discourse on the Method” (the one with "I think, therefore I am"). It introduced a radical way of thinking, which we now call the scientific method. Indeed, the rest of the title is “…of Correctly Conducting One’s Reason and Seeking Truth in the Sciences”. It was radical. Few people thought that way at the time (Galileo had published his Dialogue only 5 years before). Amazingly, the book also defines the goals of a future discipline: neuroscience! [1/4]

item.title: Matteo Carandini
item.description:
He wrote them in a paragraph that reads like a to-do list: neuroscientists needs to explain what changes must occur in the brain to cause states of waking, sleeping, and dreaming;
 how light, sounds, smells, tastes, heat, and all the other qualities of external objects can imprint various ideas on the brain through the intermediary of the senses;
 how hunger, thirst, and the other internal passions can also transmit ideas to the brain;[2/4]

item.title: Matteo Carandini
item.description:
 what [is] the 'common sense' in which these are received,
 the memory which preserves them,
 and the faculty of imagination, which can change them in different ways,
 form them into new ideas,
 and [...] distribute 'animal spirits' to the muscles and make the [...] body move
 with respect both to the objects which present themselves to the senses and to the internal passionsWhen will we be able to cross off all the items from René's list? [3/4]

item.title: Matteo Carandini
item.description: We are well on our way. For instance, we have known for a century that those “animal spirits” are trains of spikes. We have known for decades how spikes can move muscles or represent complex sensory stimuli. And we have learned many more important things since then. But do we have all the facts we need to cross off the rest of the list? Or do we need more radical discoveries – on a par with the spike – before we can figure out memory, imagination, and those darned “internal passions”?[4/4]

item.title: L. Rhodes
item.description: The energy consumption of ML-generators is, of course, an environmental issue, but it's also going to be a cost issue. Right now, AI companies are defraying that cost as much as possible, often with VC money, to make integrating it seem like a good deal for companies looking to economize. But at some point, there's going to be a rug pull, and clients who have committed themselves to AI are going to have little choice but to eat that cost or lose time to rolling back their operational investment.

item.title: Benjamin Geer
item.description: @MatteoCarandini I often think of this quote from William Dement, cofounder of the Stanford Sleep Medicine Center: "As far as I know, the only reason we need to sleep that is really, really solid is because we get sleepy."
